messageBody:
RE: [junit] Digest Number 43

> The desire to have JUnit continue running a method after an
> assertion failure is simply to get a metric of test success
> to use across testing runs.  A developer may fix some aspect
> of a method but the test case will continue to fail - if
> however they could see that the number of failures in the
> test case had decreased then they would have some idea that
> they were making progress.

Maybe a new "type" of assertion could be introduced, which is like a soft assertion.  Name it something like "check".  So, if you want to check several things which are an outcome of the one action, and you want to be able to report multiple failures within the one test, you could call check() instead of assert(), but for things that would make sense to halt the test, then call assert().

I use JUnit for application-level acceptance testing of web applications (using HttpUnit - see http://httpunit.sourceforge.net) as well as just unit testing, and having something like this I would find extremely useful.

For example, I could then do something like:

  Page loginPage = getLoginPage();
  check(loginPage.existenceOfFeature1());  // important, but not fatal
  check(loginPage.existenceOfFeature2());  // important, but not fatal
  assert(loginPage.existenceOfFeature3()); // fatal, cannot procede if fails

Gabriel
